Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (503) 427-9233 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation</div><div style="text-align: center;">
<div style="background: rgb(255, 255, 255); border: 0px; font-family: 'Segoe UI', helvetica, arial, sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 21px; margin: 0px; outline: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left; vertical-align: baseline;"><div style="text-align: left;"><div style="background-color: white; line-height: 18px; margin-bottom: 8px; text-overflow: ellipsis; word-wrap: break-word;"><div style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: initial; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 6pt;">Today, Shelby Spencer of Primary Residential Mortgage joins us to discuss some of the changes to FHA Guidelines starting September 14.

</div><div style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: initial; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 6pt; text-overflow: ellipsis; word-wrap: break-word;">The biggest change to look out for is with student loans, which can no longer be removed from the debt ratio if they are deferred. This means that all contracts or offers written after September 14 will be affected by these changes. Another change comes to large deposits; we used to only need to source large deposits of around 2% of the sales price, but deposits of 1% or more now need to be documented. In addition to these changes, know that funds can no longer be used as assets; you can’t create a stronger profile with gift funds, although they can be used as a down payment.


<div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"></div><div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;">
</div></div><div style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: initial; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 6pt; text-overflow: ellipsis; word-wrap: break-word;">With the inventory as tight as it is; there is a good chance some of the pre-approved FHA buyers may find themselves losing their previously issued pre-approved status before they get an accepted offer. The new FHA guidelines take effect with FHA case numbers assigned on or after 9/14/15. (Case numbers can only be assigned when a property has been identified.)</div><div style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: initial; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 6pt; text-overflow: ellipsis; word-wrap: break-word;">
</div><div style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: initial; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 6pt; text-overflow: ellipsis; word-wrap: break-word;">The following bullet points are just a few of the areas that could affect buyers. I recommend that all FHA pre-approved buyers contact their loan officer to review their situation against the new guidelines. Here are some of the areas that are affected (I will cover them in more detail soon):</div><div style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: initial; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 6pt; text-overflow: ellipsis; word-wrap: break-word;"></div><ul><li>Federal Tax Liens</li><li>Mixed Use Property</li><li>Bankruptcy less than 2 years</li><li>Occupant borrower has no credit score</li><li>Self-employed borrower’s income is greater than 20% declining from the previous year</li><li>Installment debts with less than 10 months remaining</li><li>Deferred loan payments (student loans)</li><li>30-day credit accounts</li><li>More than 3 jobs and/or profession changes in the last 12 months</li><li>2- to 4-unit properties</li><li>Retaining current home as a rental</li><li>Nontaxable income (like social security income)</li><li>Earnest money deposits greater than 1% of sales price</li><li>Using gifted funds for any reserve requirements</li></ul>
<div style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: initial; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 6pt; text-overflow: ellipsis; word-wrap: break-word;">As long as everyone is aware of these changes up front, closing times shouldn’t be too affected. Of course, the best way to prepare yourself for these changes is to reach out to a professional and begin the process sooner than later. You can reach Shelby at SSpencer@Primeres.com or (503) 572-8865. Of course, if you have questions or concerns on the real estate side of things, don’t hesitate to reach out to us. We would love to hear from you!</div></div></div></div></div>
